entry.title: Combined summary - Request review: drop misbehaving peers
entry.summary: The Bitcoin-development mailing list has been discussing the implementation of DoS (Denial-of-Service) protection in Bitcoin transactions. The proposed mechanism involves punishing peers who send obviously wrong information by dropping connections and banning IP addresses, with the probability of punishment depending on the severity of the behavior. Misbehavior/ban information would be stored only in memory, and information about misbehaving peers is never broadcasted. However, there are concerns about what is considered misbehavior and whether sending lots of messages that don't pass the protocol-level checksum test should be a bannable offense. Furthermore, non-standard transactions or those with insufficient fees should not be penalized as they are properly relay/miner policy decisions and should be made more easily configurable, not punished for configuration.During the discussion, suggestions were made to improve the DoS protection scheme, such as adding a -banscore option that bans nodes accumulating more than -banscore misbehavior points. There were also suggestions to implement some sort of choking/unchoking in order to warn peers that they might be dropped if they continue to misbehave. However, there are concerns that any kind of peer disconnection should not be present in the reference client implementation as it would limit future innovation. It is suggested that this type of filtering may be better implemented in a separate bitcoin proxy, similar to how a firewall can be placed between a router and network.In addition to the discussion around DoS protection, there were debates about various proposals related to DoS protection, such as sending a message to the banned peer with a code indicating the reason for the ban, treating a block with too many sigops as invalid, and using a mutable field with a const setter. The consensus was that a -banscore option will be added, and bad signatures will be a banning offense, while the other issues will be made more easily configurable.Another topic discussed in the context is how to handle potential denial-of-service (DoS) attacks, with Gavin Andresen advocating for failing hard and logging the reason locally. He believes that response messages would only give attackers another potential attack vector and that debug logs make it clear what triggers a ban. However, he supports the imposition of transaction rules so that dropping is not pointless due to the possibility of junk transactions being used in an attack. Andresen suggests that nodes should only drop transactions that would invalidate a block if included in it, but this raises issues with double spends.There were also discussions on various proposals related to DoS protection, such as sending a message to the banned peer with a code indicating the reason for the ban, treating a block with too many sigops as invalid, and using a mutable field with a const setter. The conversation also includes suggestions for improvements to the DoS protection scheme, such as adding a -banscore option that bans nodes accumulating more than -banscore misbehavior points. Overall, the discussion highlights the importance of carefully considering the impact of network rules and avoiding hanging up on nodes that may simply be too young to know better.The context involves a review of a pull request regarding "non-standard" transactions and their treatment in the Bitcoin network. Some argue that assigning a small penalty is reasonable for those who try to send non-standard transactions, while others maintain that standardness is an artificial construct and that penalizing for personal policies could result in banning legitimate nodes. However, it is acknowledged that the vast majority of transactions follow a particular pattern, and that emitting dozens or hundreds of non-standard transactions is suspicious behavior that may warrant disconnecting from the network. The conversation also touches on the issue of DoS attacks and how to prevent them. One member disagrees with the current implementation of -maxreceivebuffer, which they believe could lead to memory exhaustion and does nothing to prevent network flooding. Another member suggests keeping comments on-topic and avoiding snarky remarks in bitcoin-dev discussions. The discussion highlights the importance of balancing security measures with flexibility and avoiding overly restrictive policies that may hinder future development.
